text:
One thing I have to ask you,
since you've worked with the river

and the people of the river for so long.
Even in the last 17 years,

what has the impact of climate change
been on the river and its people?

So when I started,
there were two things which I knew.

This was in 2003. When people asked,
"What is it that you need?

What would you say
is the threat through all your work?"

Two things we could never 
move away from:
one was environment
and the geography.

Second was the deep, 
deep way of working,

ensuring human rights are
never infringed on.
Okay, now,

when we started our work, 
people did not -

people had never had
healthcare there.

I mean, people come in, give some medicines 
and go away. But it's different.
It was at

a certain economic and social level,
as well as access level.

We have improved that,
I think, multiplied it by hundreds.

But the point is that 
the climate impact,

on the other hand, 
is pushing it down
again, with a multiplying effect.
So we used to get floods,

say the first year, and the 
10th year we had two floods.
Over the last few years,

We have had multiple 
floods every year.

So can you imagine
 the link with poverty?

You plant 100% of 
your savings into the crops,

all gone with unpredicted floods.
Your land is washed away.
People migrating,
new migrations coming in,
and of course, insecurity increases.
